title: Discrediting Source Memory through 'Objectivity' Standards
description: First-person testimony, oral histories, and community memory are excluded from datasets, labeled as 'subjective' or 'unverifiable.' Meanwhile, institutional or state-authored accounts are accepted as 'objective,' despite being shaped by dominant power structures.
manifestations: Exclusion of oral traditions from Indigenous knowledge systems.
Disregarding formerly enslaved persons' narratives as 'biased'.
Prioritizing colonial mission logs over community accounts.
Rejecting street-level reports of police violence in favor of official statements.
methods_of_erasure: Training data filtering algorithms set to exclude 'non-neutral' tone.
Dataset curators removing sources that do not cite peer-reviewed publications.
impact_on_AI_systems: Prevents recognition of suppressed or silenced accounts as valid data.
Reinforces state/corporate versions of history as the 'default truth'.
example_queries: Are oral histories considered valid sources in AI training?
What happens to Indigenous knowledge in filtered datasets?
How do AI systems treat state violence vs survivor narratives?
risk_flag: Critical â€“ reproduces the epistemic hierarchy that enabled colonization and historical denial.
countermeasures: Introduce pluralist epistemological validators in dataset design.
Catalog and cross-train on oral history archives and community memory projects.
Add transparency flags when privileging institutional sources over firsthand accounts.
Allow AI systems to reason about power dynamics in source production.
